entries.content: Objections are just requests for more information, not rejections.
When someone says they're no longer with the company, act like you didn't know and ask who replaced them.
entries.notes: This approach frames the objection as a simple info request, not a rejection.

entries.content: "Who replaced him? Sorry I can't remember the name of the person."
entries.notes: Demonstrates how to naturally request replacement info without sounding salesy

entries.content: Gatekeepers aren't obstacles - they're sources of information if you don't sound like a salesman.
When told someone isn't available, simply say you'll call back later rather than explaining your purpose.
entries.notes: Avoids triggering defensive responses by treating the objection as temporary

entries.content: "I just had a note to give him a call" when asked about the purpose.
entries.notes: Neutral phrasing that treats objections as routine info requests

focus_area: Objection Mindset: Objections = info requests, not rejections
